kdl.prox.dbmgr
Class FilterFactory

java.lang.Object
  kdl.prox.dbmgr.FilterFactory

public class FilterFactory
extends java.lang.Object

Given a string description of a filter, a-la SQL, it returns an actual instance of the Filter* hierarchy that implements it.

Valid filters:

  • colName DISTINCT ROWS
  • colName LIKE value
  • colName BETWEEN lowerBound-upperBound
  • colName IN batVariableName
  • colName NOTIN batVariableName
  • colName KEYIN batVariableName
  • colName KEYNOTIN batVariableName
  • colName OP value
  • colName OP colName
  • colName RANDOM count
  • * (no filter)
OP is any of the types listed in ComparisonOperatorEnum (see)

Filters can be combined with AND and OR, using infix notation, e.g. col1 LIKE 'a' OR col2 EQ 'b' AND col3 IN batVar1

The following rules apply to combined filters:

  • the DISTINCT ROWS filter cannot be combined with other filters
  • No parenthesis are allowed, and the filters are processed in pairs in the order in which they appear.
For example, the filter a AND b OR c is processed as (a AND b) OR c. Similarly, a AND b OR c AND d is processed as ((a AND b) OR c) AND d

Note that AND and OR will be interpreted as the logical connectors in positions every three words AND EQ 7, refering to a column named AND, will generate an error. But A EQ 6 AND and EQ 7 will work.

See Also:
ComparisonOperatorEnum

isInFilter

public static boolean isInFilter(java.lang.String filterDescr)
Returns true when the filter involves a KEYIN/NOTIN or IN/NOT operator. In that case, the filter will most likely involve columns that don't belong to the same NST

Parameters:
filterDescr -
Returns:
